reviews.review_msg: This course was his first delivered online. The timeline of getting recorded lectures was sporadic. He prepares minimal slides for his lectures so you need to pay close attention to what he says. The major assignments were all due at the end of the semester, which made it hard to know how he grades. Turns out he has very high expectations.

Do not take unless mandatory for your degree. Class is an introduction to humanities yet I've never been more confused in a humanities class before. The professor is inconsistent with his rubric and docks grades for criteria he fails to mention. Never shows up to class with prepared slides just stands and talks in the front for the duration.

Lectures were confusing and he rarely had slides ready for class. With the TSSU strike many concepts were skimmed over or skipped completely. Second paper ended up being worth 40% of the total grade and the grading rubric was changed mid semester without any guidance. Tough grader, unclear, unorganized and came to class unprepared.

The topics and readings were very interesting, and the class discussions were great. However, there is some sense that topics not necessarily relate to one another (and he does not do a great job helping there). His grading is really unclear despite the rubric. The feedback is minimal and appears unimportant, yet his grading is tough

One of the worst profs I've ever had. Boring, inconsistent, and a terrible grader. Rubrics and comments constantly have one-word responses next to incomplete grades, with absolutely NO feedback or suggestions on what you can fix to improve your mark. Avoid classes with him if you value your sanity.
The professor is nice and talketive but he is a tough grader. Classes are long but enjoyable and get ready to ready.

Fairly interesting topics, good crossover between modern and ancient topics. Lots of reading, some pretty difficult to follow along with, but he is extremely fair and takes feedback seriously to improve the course. Flexible with deadlines if he sees that people are struggling. Overall good prof and enjoyed the course

Samir is a great person and cares about his students. However, unless this class is required for your major I would avoid it due to the work load. Average 2hrs of reading a week + 1hr homework (if you know what you're doing) on top of regular class time. Must participate in tutorials each class for marks. Not a GPA booster, concepts can be hard.

I am currently in his Hum 101W class & this is only our 3rd class and I feel a little lost. He makes great discussion in the class but I feel like he digress a lot and does not provide good lecture notes or guidelines for that matter. I'm a biology student & I'm used to clear notes. I wish he was more organized. Prepare to read 8 different textbook

He is an amazing teacher, and really cares about his students. Gandesha values everyones differing opinions and thoughts, and often provokes insightful ideas. There is a lot of reading but it was his first time running this course. He very much is polisci so keep up to date with the news, but he is lovely so if you do the homework you will be fine.
Difficult class, but Samir made it super interesting. Definitely not a clear-cut syllabus, so it's important to attend lectures and take the time to understand the material.

Definitely knows his stuff...except he can't communicate well with his students. He mumbles in class so it's really hard to hear him. He treats it like a 4th year class too! He's very unorganized with last-minute slides full of typos and is a fickle. Be prepared to do lots of readings. Could've been way more interesting...

Class was enjoyable, discussions were always interesting and challenging. Encourages critical thinking. Assignments were fair, final paper was 10-12 pages and involved analyzing a real-world issue using the class readings. Which is a lot better than abstract philosophy!

I recommend taking this class, because it's one of the very few dedicated to the theme of nihilism. Class discussions were always relevant and engaging, however he tends to go off on tangents. One of the drawbacks is their is much more sporadic course content (no exams), so it may be hard to pull it all together. Assignments are fair, though.

Amount of reading was decent (7 books, 2 essays - but SHORT ones), and material was really well connected with social, political, and philosophical issues. Lack of an exam means what you learn is equal to the effort you put in, rather than rote memorization. Reasonably accessible and helpful - encourages discussion, passionate about the humanities.

He really knows what he's talking about, however, he seems to expect too much from his students. Over all it was a very interesting class, because he was able to relate the content very well to modern society, but there was way to much reading required.

He is friendly enough and teaches somewhat comprehensively. However, he is terribly unorganized and expects way too much for a 100 level introductory course. He is very last minute and ambiguous in his directions. it caused me alot of stress during the semester. the amount of work i put into the course didn't reflect in my grade at all.

Great Prof. Very intelligent yet approachable. He is unarguably invested in his work and in students demonstrating some level of academic engagement. I suspect that most of these negative comments are from students undertaking HUM courses for "easy" breadth requirements - b/c HUM is a small dept, most courses do not have prereqs. Now you know.

VERY boring. Droned on and on about stuff unrelated to the class. 10 textbooks, two 10 page papers, no time to do all that! NOT a 100level course. GET A GOOD TA, I got a terrible one. I talked to Gandesha about issues with my TA and he disregarded it. Worst course I've ever taken.

This guy butchered HUM 101 for me big time! Not only are his lectures BORING, but he drones on and on in tutorial! Texts were interesting, but he didn't really do anything engaging to him. Not helpful at all.

At first I found his lecture style made me a bit sleepy, but then I woke up and realized he was REALLY interesting. Excellent prof,more than fair, show him you're interested and you'll do fine. Assignments were challenging, but he is a fair marker. Too many books to read, but at least they were all short.
Really nice. Lectures were sometimes irrelevant, but a great course. I enjoyed it.
Worst class ever... can't hear a word he's saying. wears super weird suits. need to read 4 books a week... 10-14paged essays... pointless.

You can't learn anything from Samir that you can't read in a mediocre book that might cost you a dollar fifty in late late fee's at the local library. Look into his career history and talk to some people... why is he teaching this? then ask how. or,you can take my word for it and find a different and worthwhile prof to spend your time and money on.

Overly professional to a point where it affects learning... yea, professionalism is great but not at the expense of the chemistry of classroom learning. That said, his knowledge seems great only because knows more than the students who have posted here. A passive aggressive who fails to sort concepts for average learner...i taught myself this cours
Really eloquent and passionate, but difficult to approach. A fair but hard marker.
This was avery challenging class, but his passion for the material and his breadth of knowledge were really inspiring.

He is actually a very good prof.  He's clear most of the time and when he's not you can ask him to clarify and he will.  He's also really good with criticisms of the works (he's not a my way or the highway type guy). His professionalism is a bit intimidating at times, but don't let that scare you, he's super nice. he has a wealth of knowledge!
This guy needs to seriously evaluate his teaching methods. Humanities is a flakey enough subject without jerks like Samir teaching it.

Samir is particularly good at keeping the discussion going and on track, guiding it gently away from nonsense without being harsh. Don't expect him to lecture a lot, but that's fine. And he's very encouraging to students who are serious about learning.

heyyy now he wasnt that bad.  yes he did cancel lectures cuz his kids were sick, and a time or two more for who knows why...but he was a nice guy.  he sends out his notes via email too, so if you just read over those and add some original thoughts, you'll do just dandy on his exams.
Samir can be a bit of a flake (he's forgotten notes and cancelled classes on short notice), but the things he teaches are really interesting and class discussions are fantastic.
No Comments

Who the hell assigns 9 textbooks for a 13 week 100 level class? Obviously this prof is way over himself and thinks that his students have no other classes. I'm sorry, but my life is not going to focus around you and your incompetent teaching abilities.

Where on earth did this guy come from? Absolutely boring, uninteresting, disengaging, and does not deserve the privelage of teaching this course. Waaay too many readings for what this course is. This prof needs some serious help.
Horrible, borrrrring, etc
